questions.question: What is the hybrid-π model?
options: A nonlinear model for large-signal BJT analysis
A linear small-signal equivalent circuit derived from h-parameters by neglecting h_re and h_oe
A thermal model for predicting transistor temperature
A DC model for calculating the Q-point
questions.explanation: The hybrid-π model is a linearised small-signal equivalent circuit obtained from the general h-parameter model by setting h_re ≈ 0 and h_oe ≈ 0 (or R_out → ∞). It replaces the nonlinear BJT with r_π and a dependent current source for AC analysis around the Q-point.

questions.question: What is the transconductance g_m?
options: g_m = I_CQ / V_T — the ratio of DC collector current to thermal voltage
questions.explanation: g_m = I_CQ/V_T relates the small-signal collector current to the base-emitter voltage: i_c = g_m·v_be. At room temperature with V_T = 26 mV, a 1 mA bias gives g_m = 38.5 mA/V. Crucially, g_m does not depend on β.

questions.question: What is r_π?
options: The external resistor in the emitter
The small-signal input resistance looking into the base: r_π = β/g_m = βV_T/I_CQ
The thermal resistance of the transistor package
questions.explanation: r_π = h_ie is the small-signal resistance between base and emitter. It equals β/g_m = βV_T/I_CQ. Unlike g_m, r_π does depend on β. Higher β or lower I_CQ gives a larger r_π (higher input impedance).

questions.question: If I_CQ = 2 mA and β = 100, what is g_m? (V_T = 26 mV)
questions.explanation: g_m = I_CQ/V_T = 2 mA / 26 mV = 76.9 mA/V. Note that β is not needed for this calculation — g_m depends only on the bias current and thermal voltage.

questions.question: With g_m = 76.9 mA/V and β = 100, what is r_π?
questions.explanation: r_π = β/g_m = 100/76.9 mA/V = 1300 Ω = 1.3 kΩ. Alternatively: r_π = βV_T/I_CQ = 100×26mV/2mA = 2600/2 = 1300 Ω. Both give the same answer.

questions.question: What is r_e, and how does it relate to r_π?
options: r_e = 1/g_m = V_T/I_CQ, and r_π = β × r_e
r_e is the external emitter resistor R_E
questions.explanation: r_e = 1/g_m = V_T/I_CQ ≈ 26mV/I_CQ (mA). It's the intrinsic small-signal emitter resistance. It relates to r_π by r_π = β·r_e — the base 'sees' the emitter resistance multiplied by β because the base current is β times smaller.

questions.question: Why is g_m independent of β?
options: Because β cancels out in the derivation: g_m = β/r_π = β/(βV_T/I_CQ) = I_CQ/V_T
Because g_m is a property of the packaging, not the semiconductor
Because g_m is defined to exclude β by convention
g_m is actually dependent on β, but the dependence is weak
questions.explanation: g_m = β/r_π. Since r_π = βV_T/I_CQ, substituting: g_m = β/(βV_T/I_CQ) = I_CQ/V_T. The β in the numerator and denominator cancel exactly. This is why g_m depends only on the Q-point current and the thermal voltage.

questions.question: When can you drop R_out (= 1/h_oe) from the hybrid-π model?
options: When R_out >> R_L (the load resistance), so it doesn't significantly affect the circuit
questions.explanation: R_out appears in parallel with the load at the output. When R_out >> R_L (typically R_out > 10 R_L), most of the current flows through R_L and R_out has negligible effect. Since R_out is typically 100k–1MΩ and R_L is typically 1k–10kΩ, this condition is almost always met.

questions.question: The hybrid-π model should be used for:
options: DC analysis to find the Q-point
Small-signal AC analysis around the Q-point
questions.explanation: The hybrid-π model is valid only for small-signal AC analysis around the DC operating point (Q-point). You must first find the Q-point using DC analysis (with the nonlinear model), then use the hybrid-π model to analyse how small AC signals are amplified.

questions.question: Which h-parameters are neglected in the simplified hybrid-π model?
options: h_re (reverse voltage feedback) and h_oe (output admittance)
questions.explanation: h_re ≈ 10⁻⁴ (negligible reverse feedback) and h_oe ≈ 10⁻⁶ S (very high output resistance, effectively infinite). Dropping these leaves h_ie = r_π (input resistance) and h_fe = β (forward current gain), giving the simplified two-element model.
